Hi Per,

I just realized I'm going of topic even for the list so I start a new thread
and try to keep it short :)

I think testdriving Java with RSpec is really interesting. I haven't made up
my mind why,
maybe I'm just envious of the cool Ruby stuff and want to squeese it in just
because I can or there is
some better reason why I'm interested.

The hole I tried to fill is when you have a mixed environment of JRuby and
Java and
you want your feedback in one place. The solution should work for idea and
netbeans aswell
so it's not just for eclipse (just wanted to emphasize that in case someone
missed it)

When I had that done I just started thinking "hey, why not test-drive
java-code as well"
and that's about as far as I have come in that line of thoughts.
What is your experience with testing java-code from RSpec? (you seem to have
thought
some more about it than me)

I can see that some problems can emerge like the one you had with the
exception-class thingy...
Is it possible to just raise a Java exception (without rspec). In that case
I guess you could work around
the problem by specifying your own action for throwing java-exceptions. If
the problem lies deeper
withing JRuby so that you can't even raise Java exceptions it becomes more
difficult :)

/J

On 9/10/07, Per Jacobsson <perjacobsson@...> wrote:
>
>   I like the idea of testing Java classes with rspec and have been playing
> around with it myself. Integrating it with the JUnit runner in Eclipe
> would definitely be useful.
>
> One gotcha I ran into was where Exceptions thrown by the rspec mocks
> didn't get the right type in Java. See this Jruby bug -
> http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/JRUBY-1127
>
> / Per

> Hi all, I have been playing with JRuby recently and in particular how
> to embed Ruby in Java applications. I believe that mixing languages
> rather than switching completely from one language to another is going
> to be more and more important. As I explored the subject i found
> myself lacking some tools. I was frustrated by the fact that I had to
> maintain two sets of tests and look for feedback in two different
> locations while developing.
>
> I created a custom runner for JUnit to address the subject and I think
> it looks promising. I created a blog entry with some more details in
> case anyone is interested:
>
> http://johlrogge.wordpress.com/2007/09/08/hybrid-theory/
> <http://johlrogge.wordpress.com/2007/09/08/hybrid-theory/>
>
> I have some loose plans on open-sourcing this but I would like to see
> if there are others than me that find this interesting enough to be
> worth the effort before I do.
>
> /Joakim Ohlrogge
